title: 107_hr516
content: The "Apples for Teachers Act" exempts qualified professional development expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers from the 2-percent floor on miscellaneous itemized deductions. The "Apples for Teachers Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow deductions for qualified professional development expenses of eligible teachers, exempting them from the 2-percent floor on miscellaneous itemized deductions. The "Apples for Teachers Act" allows deductions for qualified professional development expenses of eligible teachers, including tuition, fees, books, supplies, equipment, and transportation for enrollment in a course directly related to the curriculum they teach. The "Apples for Teachers Act" allows deductions for qualified professional development expenses of eligible teachers, including instruction to enhance understanding and use of State standards, teaching children with different learning styles, and disciplining children effectively. The "Apples for Teachers Act" emphasizes disciplining children effectively in the classroom, aligning with State standards, and implementing proven strategies to improve student academic achievement. The "Apples for Teachers Act" requires professional development for teachers to positively impact their classroom performance, excluding short-term workshops. The development must be part of an approved program and align with a comprehensive professional development plan. The "Apples for Teachers Act" mandates professional development for eligible teachers, defined as kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers in elementary or secondary schools. The development must be approved by the local educational agency and align with the Act's goals. The "Apples for Teachers Act" requires professional development for eligible teachers in kindergarten through grade 12 at elementary or secondary schools. The definitions of 'elementary school' and 'secondary school' are based on the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The amendments will be effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2000. SEC. 30B. CREDIT TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS WHO PROVIDE CLASSROOM MATERIALS. This section provides a tax credit to teachers who supply classroom materials. The tax code allows eligible teachers to claim a credit for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses up to $400 per year. Eligible teachers include kindergarten through grade 12 classroom teachers, instructors, counselors, aides, or principals on a full-time basis. Qualified expenses cover books and supplies. The tax code allows eligible teachers to claim a credit for education expenses such as books, supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials used in the classroom. The term "elementary or secondary school" refers to any school providing education up to grade 12. Special rules include denying double benefits and limiting the credit amount based on other credits. The tax code allows eligible teachers to claim a credit for education expenses. Excess of regular tax reduced by credits over tentative minimum tax. Taxpayers can elect to not apply this section for any taxable year. The tax code provides a credit for elementary and secondary school teachers who purchase classroom materials. Effective starting in taxable years after December 31, 2000.
